prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the "Am I the Asshole" post is in the wrong. The situation is about the husband setting up his home office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the author who also works from home and handles most household chores and kids. 

First, I need to break down the key points. The husband works from home a few days a week, chose the bedroom over the basement despite the wife's suggestion. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs silence. But because he's in the bedroom, the wife can't use the top floor, can't take a shower, do chores, etc. She's also working from home and dealing with the kids. She told him that if he's in the basement, they won't disturb him, but if he stays in the bedroom, she can't guarantee silence. Now they're fighting about who's the asshole.

The question is whether the author (the wife) is in the wrong. The answer options are A (yes) or B (no). 

I need to consider both sides. The husband chose the bedroom for the view, which might be a personal preference, but it's causing significant disruptions. The wife is handling most of the household and work, so her ability to function is being blocked. The husband's job requires silence, but setting up in the bedroom where the family is active seems to create a conflict of needs. 

The wife is trying to balance both her work and household duties. By choosing the basement, she's offering a space where he can work undisturbed, which would free up the top floor for her. His refusal to move to the basement might be selfish, prioritizing his comfort over her practical needs. 

On the other hand, the husband is working and needs a quiet environment. But if the bedroom is a shared space, maybe he should have considered that. The wife's argument is that she can't promise silence if he's in the bedroom, which is fair because that's where the family activities are. 

I think the key here is the husband not being flexible. The basement is available, so moving there would solve the problem. The wife isn't at fault for not keeping him undisturbed when he's in a space that's part of the living area. She's also managing a lot, and his choice is hindering her ability to work and take care of the house. So the author isn't in the wrong; the husband is being unreasonable. So the answer should be B (No).
